questions.question_text: Why do Cisco MPLS TE tunnels require a link-state routing protocol?

discussion.content: D is correct. A link-state routing protocol is required because link information, such as available bandwidth is crucial for the operation of TE tunnels.

Information distribution is a link state protocol, such as Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) or Intermediate System-to-Intermediate System (IS-IS), which is necessary to discover the topology. These protocols have been enhanced to carry additional information related to TE, such as bandwidth available and other related parameters. IS-IS uses new Type Length Values (TLVs) and OSPF uses Type 10 (Opaque) Link State Advertisements (LSAs) for this purpose. Other IGPs cannot be used to implement MPLS TE.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-knowledge-base/how-mpls-traffic-engineering-works/ta-p/3128593

choices.D: The tunnel endpoints use the link-state database to evaluate the entire topology and determine the best path.
choices.B: The link-state database provides a data repository from which the tunnel endpoints can dynamically select a source ID.
choices.C: Link-state routing protocols use SPF calculations that the tunnel endpoints leverage to implement the tunnel.
choices.A: The link-state database provides segmentation by area, which improves the path-selection process.

questions.question_text: Which two PHY modes are available to implement an IOS XR 10 Gigabit Ethernet interface? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
AD are correct.
Search the doc for Table 1. show controllers wanphy Command Output Fields

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct based on https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs_r6-1/interfaces/command/reference/b-interfaces-cr-crs-61x/b-interfaces-cr-crs-61x_chapter_010010.html

Would of thought A & D would be the correct answers?

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs_r4-1/interfaces/command/reference/interfaces_cr41crs_chapter19.html

questions.question_text: According to RFC5305 on IS-1S extensions for traffic engineering, what is the 4-octet sub-TLV type 10 of extended IS-IS reachability TLV type 22?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the fastest way and it has minimum posible changes

choices.A: Implement BGP local preference on R2
choices.D: Implement BGP in the default configuration on R1
choices.C: Implement BGP MED metrics on R2
choices.B: Implement BGP weight capabilities on R1

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit, R1 is connected to multiple BGP-enabled routers that are located in different autonomous systems. R1 has been configured with a BGP neighbor configuration, and all next hops are reachable with the ICMP protocol. A network engineer is examining traffic flow to the FTP server with IP address 134.44.14.10 to support a policy map implementation. The solution should require the minimum possible configuration changes. What should the engineer do to influence the best path route selection algorithm to forward all traffic from R1 via next-hop R2 with IP address 10.114.21.1?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Company A is connected to multiple upstream ISPs, with ISP_A serving as the primary upstream ISP. The company A subnet 172.43.232.0 should be announced to the secondary ISP_B only when the FTP server with IP address 10.10.1.1 is not accessible via the primary ISP. Which configuration must be applied on R1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct ansewer
